critique: This executive order establishes a cooperative education program within the federal government, allowing students to gain work experience in federal agencies while pursuing a bachelor's degree. It enables the noncompetitive conversion of these students to career positions upon graduation, subject to certain conditions and agency recommendations. The order also tasks the Civil Service Commission with prescribing regulations for the program's implementation and evaluation. It revokes a previous executive order on the same topic. The document itself does not explicitly promote any ideological agenda. It seems to be a workforce development initiative. There is no mention of immigration. The order delegates authority to the Civil Service Commission, but it does not dramatically expand executive power. It does not directly address federalism. It does not directly impact national security or civil liberties. It could be seen as a form of government intervention in workforce development, but it is not heavy-handed. It does not directly address social inclusion, but the program could potentially promote diversity within the federal workforce.
